sub_title: International lawyer (international criminal law, human rights, international humanitarian law, and refugee law)
summary:
I have more than 20 years of working experience in the fields of international criminal law, international human rights, international humanitarian law, and refugee law. 

I have working and consultancy experience from several international courts and tribunals, including the International Criminal Court, the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts in Cambodia, the Kosovo Specialist Chambers, and the Special Tribunal for Lebanon. Between 2005 and 2017, I worked in ICTY Chambers (pre-trial, trial, and appeal-stage), managing a team of legal officers. The cases I worked on include the Haradinaj et al. case, the Gotovina et al. case, and the Stanišić and Simatović case. Between 2011 and 2017, I was the Senior Legal Officer and team leader of the legal team supporting the Judges on the Mladić case (see http://www.internationalcrimesdatabase.org/Commentary/IcdBriefs2018). I previously worked with human rights and refugee law at Amnesty International and the Swedish Helsinki Committee (Civil Rights Defenders). Between 2001 and 2003, I lived in Kosovo and worked at the Ombudsperson Institution as Legal Officer and Director of Investigations. 

During the last 20 years I have lectured and published extensively on international criminal law and human rights. I was a member of the editorial committee of the Journal of International Criminal Justice for more than 10 years. Since January 2019, I am the co-editor for Commentary on the Law of the International Criminal Court, together with Professor Mark Klamberg (https://www.cilrap-lexsitus.org/clicc). My previous publications include articles for the Oxford Companion to International Criminal Justice (Antonio Cassese, Ed.) and in distinguished journals, including the American Journal of International Law and the Nordic Journal of International Law.

volunteer_experiences.role: Member of Scientific Advisory Committee, International and European Criminal Law Observatory on Cultural Issues, Human Rights, and Security
volunteer_experiences.description: The International and European Criminal Law Observatory on Cultural Issues, Human Rights, and Security (IECLO-CUHRSE) is a legal and multidisciplinary network based at the Department of Legal Sciences (DSG) of the University of Salerno (UNISA), Italy. The Observatory aims to enhance the resources, skills, and expertise of DSG and UNISA through developing scientific collaboration networks with scholars, practitioners, and institutions active in the fields of criminal law and criminal justice at the international, European, and national level to promote the fight against impunity for crimes of global concern.

Guest lecturer at the Stockholm Centre for International Law and Justice (Stockholm University), titled "The Mladić case - International Criminal Justice at a Cross-Roads. 

On 22 November 2017, the ICTY rendered the judgment in its final trial, in the case of Prosecutor v. Ratko Mladić. The judgment marked the end of the trial proceedings in this case and of the work of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY). The establishment of the ICTY almost 25 years earlier had come to mark the beginning of a new era for international criminal justice and its work triggered the creation of new institutions, including the International Criminal Court. The trial and judgment against Ratko Mladić is an important milestone and an opportunity to consider the way forward for international criminal justice. As one of the biggest war crimes trials in history, it presents numerous challenges and lessons that are relevant for all other present and future international courts and tribunals. 

See also http://www.scilj.se/event/mladic-trial-international-criminal-justice-crossroads/

Two-day training for 30 Lebanese lawyers in Beirut (Lebanon) on 19-20 April 2018. The training focused on advocacy in international criminal proceedings.

See also: https://www.stl-tsl.org/en/media/press-releases/6275-30-lebanese-lawyers-participate-in-training-on-the-conduct-of-international-criminal-proceedings.
